answers.answer: Hi there!Well, these tests aim at looking for possible causes of neuropathy in your case. If blood sugar levels have been normal despite Type1 diabetes marker positive, diabetes is an unlikely cause, normal B12 also rules itself out as a cause with other metabolic causes and heavy metal poisoning may need to be considered in the situation. Peripheral neuropathy is generally irreversible unless an early side effect of medications and is largely managed symptomatically. The medications may take some time to act, though id these do not seem to work; a few other medications may be tried instead.Hope this is helpful.Take care!

question: I am a 46 year old female who has been an athlete her entire life.  I taught aerobics for 15 years, have been involved in martial arts, horseback riding, tennis, hiking, water skiing, snow skiing and played HS volleyball for 4 years with a scholarship to play in college.  I now swim 1 mile a day but have been diagnosed with peripheral neropathy in my feet which is debilitating.  i have "anklet" vericose veins around both ankles and swelling on a daily basis.  I have been constipated my entire life.  I drink more than enough water and eat healthy food choices whenever possible.My blood tests show a marker for type 1 diabetes and my B12 is high (most likely due to the sublingual vitamins I take). CBC is spot on, no cholesterol problems, no longer have HBP.  Blood O2 is 98% and BP is 112/64. CAT scan shows enlarged liver that is inhomogeneous with partial fatty infiltration.  Ill-defined foci of dimished attenuation within the liver adjacent to the gallbladder but no discrete hepatic mass.Gallbladder, pancreas, spleen, kidneys and adrenal glands are unremarkable.  No bowel adema or free air, no acute bony abnormality but mild, dextroconvex curvature of the thoracolumbar spine as well as degenerative disc disease at L3-4 and L4-5 exists.They have me on pain management because the pain has become debilitating.  They have started me on Lyrica but I feel no significant change.  What does all of this mean?This discussion is related to/posts/Digestive-Disorders---Gastroenterology/inhomogeneous-decreased-attenuation-of-the-liver/show/695947.
title: Inhomogenous liver with partial fatty infiltration
